body.head: Sacred Stories 27: Why the Dead are Buried

p.seg: kayâs ayîsiyiniwak ômisi kîh-pakitinikôwisiwak : kahkiyaw kêkway kîh-kitimâkêyimikwak , tahtoh kêkway kâ-wâpahtamihk , mîna êkâ kâ-wâpahtamoht . Of old men were placed here on earth by the Powers in this wise: they were pitied and befriended by every kind of thing, by as many things as are seen, and by the things that are invisible.
kahkiyaw kêkway kîh-pawâtamok . They dreamt of every kind of thing.
ahpôh wâkayôsah kîh-kiskinôhamâkwak kêkway . Even the bears taught them things.
awêk ôhci kayâs ayîsiyiniwak k-ôh-kih-manitôwicik . That is why the old-time people had manitou power. CHECK awêk. Should it be {êwak}??
êkwah nik-âtayôhkân . Now I shall tell a sacred story.

kîtahtawê yâhkih pêyak nâpêw pêyakoyiwa otawâsimisah , êkwah mistah êsah êh-kitimâkêyimât , mîna êh-miyo-pamihât . Once upon a time, long ago, a certain man had one child, and it seems that he dearly loved him and took care of him.
êkwah kîtahtawê , wayawîtimihk owîkimâkanah êh-atoskêyit , kîtahtawê kâ-wanihâcik otawâsimisiwâwah . Then at one time, as his wife was working out of doors, suddenly they lost their child.
namoya kîh-kiskêyihtamwak tânisi isi êh-isih-wanihâcik . They could not make out how they had lost track of him.
êkwah êsah mistahi pakwâtamwak , êkwanih êh-wanihâcik ôhi otawâsimisiwâwah . They were greatly distressed at having lost their child.
nâpêsisah êsah êwakw ani nistam êsah otawâsimisihtâwâw , êyakoni pikoh . The little boy had been their first child, and the only one.
nama kiskêyihtamok tânisi êy-isi-wanihâcik . They did not know how they had lost him.
êkwah pikw îtê âtah êh-kakwêcihkêmocik , êkwah piyisk pônêyimêwak . Having made inquiry everywhere, at last they gave up.
êkwah awa awâsis nik-âcimâw , tânisi êh-kîh-isih-pimâtisit . Now I shall tell of the child, how he managed to stay alive.
wâkayôs êkwah anihih awâsisah êsah kîh-kimotiw . it appears that a bear had stolen the child.
êkwah piyisk papâh-wîcêwêw , niyîpiniyikih . Soon he went about with the bear in summer-time.

êkwah kîtahtawêh itwêw awa nâpêw :
ahpôh êtokê nikosis pimâtisiw ! itwêw mâna . Then at one time that man said, “Perhaps after all my son is alive!” he would always say.
pawâtam âskaw mâna êh-wâpamât okosisah . Every now and then he would dream that he saw his son.
kîtahtawê pêponiyikih mâna kanawêyimik ôhi wâkayôsah . Then in winter-time the bear would take care of the child.
êkosi tahtoh pikw îtê ayîsiyiniwak kâ-mâmoscikêyit , âsay kiskêyihtam awa wâkayôs . As often as anywhere men performed their worship, at once the bear knew it.
ahpôh k-ôyaskinahtwâkot kiskêyihtam . He knew even when a pipe was filled for him.

ômisi êsah mâna itêw ôhi awâsisah :
nôsisê , âsay mîna ninatomikawin , itwêw êsah . This was what he must have said always to the child: “Grandchild, again I am being invited,” he must have said.
tâpwê êkotah kiy-ôhcih-pimâtisiw anah awâsis . So in this way the child stayed alive.
piyisk tâpiskôc ayîsiyiniwah kîh-itêyimêw êsah wâkayôsah , êh-owîcêwâkanit . In time he looked upon the bear, his companion, as a human person.

êkosi piyisk mihcêt askiy êh-ohpikiyikot , êkwah kêkâc êh-nâpêwit , ômisih itik wâkayôsah :
êkwah kêkâc kikîs-ôhpikin . Then finally, when the latter had brought him up through many years and he was near to manhood, the bear said to him, “Now you have almost grown up.
wîpac êkwa kitah-wayawîn , itik êsah ; Soon now you will go outside,” he must have told him;

kôhtâwiy , anohc kâ-wîh-nîpihk , kêkâc mêstihkasocih kônah , êkospih nika-nipahik , itik êsah ; “Your father, this coming spring, when the last of the snow is about to melt away, then your father will kill me,” he must have told him;

seg.gloss: “then at once do you go outside.

seg.q: kiyah êcik ôma , nôhtâh ! itâhkan , mayaw wâpamacih ;
seg.gloss: ‘And so it is you, my father!’ do you then say to him, as soon as you see him;

q.q: nôhtâh , nêwo-tipiskâw namoya ayîsiyiniw nika-wâpamik , iskwêwak têpiyâk .

seg.gloss: ‘My father, for four nights let people not see me, women at least.
You and my mother, too, I shall not see.
If women see me, I shall sink into the earth.

p.seg: kakwê-tôtah , kik-êtâw kôhtâwiy , wâpamacih , êkosih itwêw awa wâkayôs . Try to do this,’ you will say to your father when you see him” spoke that bear.
wâpahkih ka-takohtêw kôhtâwiy , itwêw êsah awa wâkayôs ; “Tomorrow your father will come,” the bear must have said;
mâka niwîh-nipahik , itêw êsah ôhi ; “But he will kill me,” he must have told the lad;
sêmâk takohtêci , kîh-nipahici , wayawîhkan , itwêw êsah . “As soon as he arrives and has killed me, then do you go outside,” he must have said.
tâpwê wiyah kisêyiniw awa êh-pê-mâcît , miskawêw wâkayôsa , itah êh-apiyit . Then truly, theold man, for his part, as he came that way on the hunt, found the bear where it was staying.
tâpwê nimiskawâw wâkayôs , itwêw êsah . “Truly, I have found a bear,” he must have said.
êkwah tâpwê nitawi-nipahêw . Accordingly, he went to kill it.
êkotêh mistikwah otinêw , ê-si-sikwâtakahikêt . There he took a long stick and prodded the hole that was in the ground.
tâpwê pê-wayawiyiwa ôhi wâkayôsah . Truly, the bear came forth.
êkwah êkos îsi nipahêw . Then, accordingly, he killed it.
mayaw ôhih wâkayôsah êh-nipahimiht , aw ôskinîkiw wayawî-kwâskohtiw . As soon as the bear had been killed, the youth leaped from the hole.
êwakw êcik âwa nôhtâwiy ! itwêw êsah . “And so this is my father!” he must have cried.

êkwah ,
tânêhki , oskinîkiw , k-ôh-isiyin ? Then, “What do you mean, youth?”
niy ôma , nôhtâh ! itwêw êsah ; “It is I, father!” he must have said;
wâkayôs ê-kîh-kimotamâsk , k-ô-kih-wanihiyin , itwêw êsah awa oskinîkiw . “Because the bear stole me from you, is why you lost me,” the youth must have said.

êkosi êh-itwêt , awa kisêyiniw ,
âyimâc niwâpamâw nikosis ! itwêw êsah . When he said this, then the old man must have said, “At last I see my son!”

nôhtâh , ôm pikoh pîci-nayômiyin , itwêw êsah awa oskinîkiw . “Father, there is only this, that you must carry me on your back,” said the youth. LB on {pîci-nayômiyin}: The prefixed particle is doubtless wrong; perhaps read {kitsi-}, which seems to be an allegro variant of (a) {kitah-isi-, kit-êsi}, i.e., {kitah-, tah-}: “that, in order that,” plus {isih-}: “thither, thus,” and (b) {kitisi-}, i.e., {isih-} with personal prefix {ki-, kit-} of second person. CHECK
tâpwê kisêyiniw okosisah wîwahôw êsah , êh-nayômât . So the old man took his son on his back and carried him.
êkwah êkotê nêwâw piko kik-âh-ayiwêpin , itêw êsa ôhtâwiya awa oskinîkiw . “And until we get there, only four times are you to stop and rest,” said the youth to his father.

tâpwê awa kisêyiniw nêyawiskôsocih ayiwêpiw ê-nayôhcikêt . So whenever the old man wearied under his burden, he rested, with his load on his back. LB on {ê-nayôhcikêt}: The normal form seems to be {nayômâw}: “he carries him on back,” {nayahtam}: “he carries it on back,” and, derived from the latter, {nayahcikêw}: “he carries on back”; but we find also {nayôhtam, nayôhcikêw}. Menomini has {nayômêw, nayôhtam}, but for the former also {nayâhêw}.

mitonih mistahi kosikwatiyiwa , pâskac êsa ostikwânihk êh-tahkopisot , iyikohk êh-miywêyihtahk okosisah êh-wâpamât . The latter was very heavy, the more so, as the old man had tied the strap round his head, so glad was he to see his son.
ohpimê wâhyaw mânokêw êsah . Then far off to one side he set up a tipi.
nêo-tipiskâw namoya nika-wâpamikwak ayîsiyiniwak , itwêw êsah . “For four nights people are not to see me,” he said.
tâpwê kisêyiniw osk-âyah papâh-ntâhtâmôw apahkwâson mîna apasoyah nêo . So the old man went about borrowing unused tent-covering and four unused tent poles.
êkwah êsah oskinîkiwah otinêw , êkâ cêskwa iskwêwah êh-âpacihâyit ; [no translation]
ayisk êsah kayâs kî-kanâtisiw ayîsiyiniw , nayêstaw kanâc-âskîhk êh-kîh-ayât . [no translation]

mâmaskâc êkwah kanawêyimêw ophimê okosisah awa kisêyiniw ; nêô-tipiskâw ayisk itik kita-ka-kanawêyimât . In a way to cause wonder then the old man guarded his son, away from the camp; for he had told him to guard him for four nights.

mwêhci nisto-tipiskâw êh-kanawêyimât , êh-nipât , kayahtê ,
nôhtâh , êkos êcik âna êkâ wîhkâc kê-wâpamiyin ! itwêw awa oskinîkiw . When he had guarded him for exactly three days and nights, as he slept, suddenly, “Father, and so you are never more to see me!” called the youth.
âsay apisîs pikoh kî-sâkiskwêw , askîhk êh-kotâwaskamikit . Already his head was but a short way above the earth, into which he was sinking.

êkosi êsa mîna kîhtwâm ,
êkosi ês ânih namoya wîhkâc kitah-âpisisin ayîsiyiniw ! itwêw êsa awa oskinîkiw ; Then once more, “And so then, it appears that never again shall a mortal man come back to life!” said that youth;

itâmaskamik kita-nahinâw ayîsiyiniw , ispîhk ohpikihitocih ! itwêw , iskwêyâc êh-pîkiskwêt awa oskinîkiw . “Under the ground man shall be laid away, as the generations go on!” said the youth, speaking for the last time.

mâka wiya awa iskwêw namoya êsa ohci wâpamêw okosisah , êkos êh-isih-nipiyit . But as for the woman, she never again saw her son, who in this wise now had died. LB on {mâka wiya awa iskwêw}: i.e., it was his mother who had violated the command; either the tale is laconically told or I missed a sentence above.
êwako pêyak âtayôhkêwin . That is one sacred story.
